all right so stegonography from the greek word steganos meaning covered and the greek word graphy meaning writing
stegonography is the process of hiding a secret message within an ordinary message and extracting it at its
destination but one important thing to note is anyone else viewing the message will
hopefully fail to identify that there's anything hidden within the message or the graphic or the
sound file
stigma has been around for hundreds of years if not thousands of years
in the greeks during the warning of an invasion they would scroll certain messages without a wooden tablet
and cover it with wax such that other people walking by these people carrying these messages would not
identify that there was a hidden message on the tablet also during world war ii there was a lot
of different types of invisible inks including vinegar milk
fruit juice and even urine which darken when heated
and i'm sure when we're all growing up we when we're traveling our parents bought some of those books where you'd have the
highlighter answer the questions okay it's actually a form of stegonography as well in the form of invisible ink
so u s government is obviously concerned about the use of steganography
not only with 9 11 but many of the other different types of attacks going on around the world
one of the common uses of it is disguising of corporate espionage there have been articles written about
employees who have been able to use steganography to steal various source
code and other things from their own company and it provides a covert mechanism by which they can distribute
this software without being caught by their own company
as we stated earlier also it's been noted in many articles as to al-qaeda and other terrorist cells
possibly using this to send messages to their other terrorist cells
to formulate various types of attacks and recently i've spoken with some
people from uh dod and nsa uh where they've been trying to tackle some child
pornography cases uh where some of these people have actually used stegonography
for hiding child pornography so with modern digital steganography
not only do we find that data is hidden within some type of digital file
but we commonly find that it's also encrypted as well therefore making it uh infinitely harder
to crack these types of files
many times they use some type of algorithm which can add or modify the contents of the file
sometimes they may simply append the data to the end of the file or hide it in the message header at the beginning
or they may distribute it throughout the file using some type of least significant bit
spread throughout the file
so just some terminology we're going to use throughout the presentation if i create a hidden message
i want to hide that within a file commonly called a carrier file
and these carrier files can include bump jpeg gif files as well as wave mp3 and
whole slew of other types of digital files

all right so let's talk about the bulk of this presentation steg analysis or essentially the identification of
hidden files so we need to define stag analysis
identifying the existence of a message but keep in mind this does not include the extraction of the message itself
simply identifying steganography a hidden message within a file
we'll talk later on about print analysis which is the actual extraction of the message okay so technically stegonography deals
with the concealment of a message not the encryption of it stig analysis essentially deals with the
detection of hidden content so we'll talk about why this is meaningful
so by identifying the existence of a hidden message perhaps we can i perhaps we can identify the tools used to hide
it if we're just going to identify that there's a hidden message there what do we really gain from this
but if we can identify what tool was used to hide the message we may possibly be able to use that same tool to extract
it so common hiding techniques typically we
find these hidden messages are either appended to the file hidden within the message header
or some special algorithm is used to disperse the message throughout the picture the file
so methods of detecting stegonography we may be able to identify it through visual detection or audible detection if
it's a wav file or an mp3 or something of that nature also
there have been some people out there such as neil provos who have used statistical analysis for identifying
hidden messages within these files a lot of times this may identify changes
within the pixels either through some type of least significant bit
or some other type of analysis such as histogram and there's also structural detection
too we have the original file we can compare it to the steganized file maybe
determine a difference in size as far as the date and the time maybe even the contents or even through
a checksum so i went ahead and kind of categorized
all of these when we talk about anomaly analysis this
includes things such as a histogram analysis or a change in the file properties or
even a statistical attack and may also include visual or audible detection as well
if we try to detect a pattern that's consistent with the program used i consider that more of a signature type
of analysis so if we routinely take the same program and hide messages in different types of
pictures we may find a pattern as to how this program hides that message within the file
so really when i went ahead and created my tool stegspy okay i really wanted to provide a couple of
goals for myself accuracy consistency and most importantly minimizing false positives really wouldn't serve any
anyone or wouldn't really be helpful if the tool went ahead and said that possibly
something is hidden in this file when in actuality it's not
so if we use visual detection okay we may or may not be able to detect that something is hidden within a picture

you're not going to be able to tell any kind of visual difference between the pictures between the original virgin
file as well as the carrier file carrying the hidden message
there's also something known as kurtosis as defined in the random house dictionary the degree of flatness or
peakedness of a curve describing a frequency of distribution
so that kind of leads us to something called histogram analysis where we actually
take a look at the frequency of each color making up that picture and determining how frequently each one of
those colors shows up so there's a number of histogram
analysis type tools out there i usually just use paintshop pro for this
open the file and run a histogram analysis on the file a normal file will show many
inconsistencies just peaks all over the place really no identifiable pattern
that may identify any type of hidden message content
but if we then compare that to a steganized file we may find some routine peaks within the histogram analysis
and this was a method proposed by eric cole and some other people out there that are really big into
stegonography personally i don't really buy into it i've done a lot of stegonography analysis and really i've only found one
program where i was able to identify hidden content using histogram analysis
another type of anomaly analysis is to compare the file properties
if you're out there doing forensic analysis you may not always have the original file you just have the steganized file

file sizes or if we run a checksum on it of course we'll get different checksums as well

many times the file that's created is the exact same size as the original file
although the checksum may be slightly different so
